questions.text: Most definitive sign of pregnancy is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most definitive sign of pregnancy is Fetal Heart Sounds (FHS). This is because the presence of fetal heart tones, typically heard between 10 to 12 weeks of gestation using a Doppler device, is a direct indicator of a living fetus within the uterus. The detection of FHS confirms that the pregnancy is progressing with a viable fetus, making it the most definitive sign of pregnancy. It indicates that the heart is beating and, by extension, confirms fetal life, which is crucial for confirming pregnancy beyond any other clinical signs or symptoms. Incorrect Options: Balottment: This is a palpable movement or a floating sensation of the fetus when the uterus is tapped or pressed. While it can be a sign of pregnancy, it is not definitive, as it typically becomes noticeable only in the second trimester (around 16-20 weeks) and may sometimes be confused with other conditions. It is considered a probable sign of pregnancy, not a definitive one. Quickening: Quickening refers to the first movements of the fetus felt by the mother, usually around 16-25 weeks of gestation. While it is an important sign that the pregnancy is progressing, it is subjective and can vary significantly from woman to woman. It is considered a presumptive sign of pregnancy, which makes it less reliable as a definitive confirmation of pregnancy. Enlarged Uterus: An enlarged uterus is a common sign of pregnancy, but it can also be caused by other conditions, such as fibroids, ovarian cysts, or even bladder distension. Therefore, while an enlarged uterus is a probable sign of pregnancy, it is not definitive, as it can occur in non-pregnant women as well.

choices.text: 60mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid
100 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid
120 mg of elemental iron and 750 micrograms of folic acid
200 mg of elemental iron and 1000 micrograms of folic acid

questions.text: Content of iron and folic acid in IFA tab distributed by government of India are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Under national programme for anemia prophylaxis dose of iron calcium are 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid. Supplementary iron therapy is needed for all pregnant mothers from 4 month onwards continued throughout preg and to be continued for 180 day post partum Folic acid supplementation (0.4 mg a day) starting 4 weeks prior to conception up to 12 weeks of pregnancy is advised. This can reduce the incidence of neural tube defects

choices.text: Give a dose to Tetanus Toxoid (TT) and explain to her that is will not protect the new born and she should take the second dose after four weeks even if she delivers in the meantime
Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would anyhow be of no use in this pregnancy
Given one dose of TT and explain that it will not be useful for this pregnancy
Give her anti-tetanus Immuno-globulin along with the TT vaccine

questions.text: A 37 weeks pregnant woman attends an antenatal clinic at a Primary Health Centre. She has not had any antenatal care till now. The best approach regarding tetanus immunization to this case would be to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer: A Explanation: Giving a dose of Tetanus Toxoid (TT) to a 37-week pregnant woman who has not received any antenatal care is the best approach. Even at this late stage, initiating the vaccination series offers crucial protection to the mother against maternal tetanus. While a single dose given so close to delivery might not guarantee optimal passive immunity transfer to the newborn to fully prevent neonatal tetanus, it still provides some level of developing protection. More importantly, it provides an opportunity to educate the mother about the importance of subsequent doses (e.g., the second dose four weeks later) for her own long-term immunity and for potential future pregnancies, ensuring she completes her immunization schedule. Incorrect Options: Option B (Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would anyhow be of no use in this pregnancy) Explanation: This is incorrect because even a single dose provides maternal protection and initiates the development of antibodies that can be transferred to the fetus, albeit possibly not to the optimal protective level for neonatal tetanus prevention if delivery is very soon. It is never a waste to provide beneficial vaccination. Option C (Given one dose of TT and explain that it will not be useful for this pregnancy) Explanation: Similar to option B, this is incorrect. The vaccine is useful for the mother's protection. While the full benefit for neonatal tetanus requires a completed series and sufficient time before delivery, it's misleading and discouraging to state it will be "not useful" for this pregnancy entirely, as some antibody transfer may occur. Option D (Give her anti-tetanus Immuno-globulin along with the TT vaccine) Explanation: Anti-tetanus Immunoglobulin (TIG) provides immediate, but temporary, passive immunity and is typically reserved for high-risk tetanus-prone wounds. It is not part of the routine antenatal immunization schedule for preventing neonatal tetanus. While TIG is given alongside TT for acute wound management, it is not the standard approach for a routine antenatal visit aiming to establish active immunity for the mother and passive immunity for the newborn

questions.text: Daily dietry calcium required in 3rd trimester of pregnancy :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dietry requirenment during pregnancy :- 1000mg in pregnant state 1500 mg during lactation 500 mg during non pregnant state The pregnancy diet ideally should be light, nutritious, easily digestible and rich in protein, minerals and vitamins. The diet should consist in addition to the principal food at least half liter, if not, 1 liter of milk (1 liter of milk contains about 1 g of calcium), plenty of green vegetables and fruits.(Ref dutta textbook of obstetrics/8th edition/112)

questions.text: Ureteric dilatation in pregnancy is due to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ureters become atonic due to high progesterone level. Dilatation of the ureter above the pelvic brim with stasis is marked on the right side especially in primigravidae. It is due to dextrorotation of the uterus pressing the right ureter against the pelvic brim and also due to pressure by the right ovarian vein which crosses the right ureter at right angle. The stasis is marked between 20–24 weeks. Where as estrogen causes marked hypertrophy of the muscle and the sheath of the ureter especially the pelvic part (Ref dutta textbook of obstetrics/8th edition/63)

questions.text: Implantation bleeding :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The correct answer is Hartman sign. Hartman sign refers to light bleeding or spotting that can occur when the embryo implants into the uterine lining, typically around 6-12 days after fertilization. This is known as implantation bleeding and occurs as a result of the embryo embedding itself into the endometrial tissue. It is often a very light, brief episode of bleeding and is considered a normal part of early pregnancy, which can sometimes be mistaken for a menstrual period. The Hartman sign is specifically associated with this process. Incorrect Options: Implantation sign: This term is too vague and not a widely recognized or specific medical term in reference to implantation bleeding. While the term may sometimes be used informally to describe the phenomenon, it does not have the same specific clinical recognition as Hartman sign. Houver's sign: Houver's sign refers to a physical finding used to describe a form of peritoneal irritation often seen in other gynecological conditions, not implantation bleeding. It is unrelated to the process of implantation and bleeding associated with early pregnancy. The Cavalier sign refers to the clinical sign of abdominal wall weakness or muscle separation that can be seen in certain cases of diastasis recti (a condition where the abdominal muscles separate, often during pregnancy).

questions.text: A mother comes with history of antenatal fetal death due to neural tube defect in first child. What is the amount of folic acid you will prescribe during preconceptional counselling (in micrograms/day)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The correct answer is 4000 micrograms (4 mg) of folic acid. For women with a history of a neural tube defect (NTD) in a previous pregnancy, the recommended dose of folic acid during preconceptional counseling is significantly higher than the standard dose to reduce the risk of recurrence. The standard dose of folic acid for most women is 400 micrograms/day, but women with a history of NTD are advised to take 4 mg (4000 micrograms) of folic acid daily starting at least one month before conception and continuing throughout the first trimester of the subsequent pregnancy. This higher dose significantly lowers the risk of another neural tube defect in a future pregnancy.

questions.text: Hegar’s sign of pregnancy is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The correct answer is (C) Softening of isthmus. Hegar’s sign is a clinical indication of early pregnancy characterized by the softening of the uterine isthmus, the portion of the uterus that connects the cervix to the body of the uterus. This occurs around 6 to 8 weeks of gestation due to hormonal changes, increased vascularity, and the development of the uterine musculature to support pregnancy. During a bimanual pelvic examination, this softening makes the isthmus more compressible, a distinguishing feature in early pregnancy. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (A) Uterine contraction: This option is incorrect because uterine contractions, such as Braxton Hicks contractions, occur later in pregnancy and are not specific signs of early pregnancy. Hegar’s sign is not related to uterine contractions but rather to the softening of the isthmus during the first trimester. (B) Bluish discoloration of vagina: This refers to Chadwick's sign, not Hegar’s sign. Chadwick's sign is the bluish discoloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix due to increased blood flow and vascularization in early pregnancy, which is also a probable sign of pregnancy but distinct from Hegar’s sign. (D) Quickening: Quickening is the perception of fetal movements by the mother, which typically occurs later in pregnancy, around 18 to 20 weeks in primigravidas and earlier in multigravidas. It is not related to the softening of the uterine isthmus and therefore unrelated to Hegar’s sign.

questions.text: An expectant mother feels quickening at:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 16-20 weeks. Quickening refers to the first perception of fetal movements by the expectant mother. It is often described as a fluttering or subtle movement in the abdomen. For primigravidas (first-time mothers), quickening usually occurs closer to 18-20 weeks of gestation, while for multigravidas (those who have been pregnant before), it may be perceived slightly earlier, around 16 weeks, due to prior experience with identifying the sensation. This range is considered normal for most pregnancies and is an important milestone that reassures the mother of fetal well-being.

questions.text: Folic acid supplementation reduces the risk of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (A) Neural tube defect. Folic acid supplementation is crucial in preventing neural tube defects (NTDs) such as spina bifida and anencephaly in the developing fetus. NTDs occur when the neural tube, which forms the brain and spinal cord, fails to close properly during early embryonic development, usually within the first 28 days after conception. Folic acid, a vital B-vitamin, supports DNA synthesis, cell division, and tissue growth, all of which are essential during early fetal development. Women of childbearing age are advised to take 400–800 micrograms daily of folic acid before conception and during early pregnancy, as this significantly reduces the risk of NTDs. Supplementation is particularly critical because the neural tube closes very early in pregnancy, often before a woman knows she is pregnant. Zinc plays a crucial role in fertility for both men and women: • In Women: Zinc supports hormonal balance, ovulation, immune function, and the health of the endometrium, all essential for conception and pregnancy. • In Men: Zinc is vital for sperm production, motility, and quality, and it supports normal testicular function and testosterone production.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of pseudocyesis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) PSEUDOCYESIS-It is a psychological disorder where the woman has the false but firm belief that she is pregnant although no pregnancy exists. The conspicuous feature is Cessation of menstruation.(AMENORRHOEA) Gradual enlargement of the abdomen because of deposition of fat, secretion from the breasts and intestinal movement, imagining it to be fetal movement. In some cases eventually spurious labor sets in. Obstetric examination reveals absence of positive signs of pregnancy. Examination with ultrasound and/or immunological tests for pregnancy may be required to negate the diagnosis.(Ref dutta textbook of obstetrics /8th edition/82)

questions.text: Term delivery implies that the gestational age of the foetus calculated from the time of onset of last menstrual period is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 40 weeks. Term delivery refers to the birth of a baby when the gestational age is between 37 and 42 weeks, calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP). However, the average duration of pregnancy is 40 weeks (280 days), which is considered the standard gestational period for a full-term delivery. This timeframe includes three trimesters and is based on the assumption of a 28-day menstrual cycle. A gestational age of 40 weeks ensures optimal development of the fetus, minimizing complications associated with preterm (before 37 weeks) or post-term (beyond 42 weeks) births. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (B) 42 weeks: This is incorrect because 42 weeks represents the upper limit of a post-term pregnancy, not the standard duration of a term delivery. Deliveries beyond 42 weeks increase the risks of complications, such as macrosomia, placental insufficiency, and stillbirth. While 42 weeks falls within the term range, it is not the average gestational age for delivery. (C) 38 weeks: While 38 weeks falls within the range of term delivery (37–42 weeks), it is considered early term, not the average gestational duration. Babies born at 38 weeks are typically healthy but may have slightly lower birth weights and a higher likelihood of requiring medical support compared to those delivered at 40 weeks. (D) 260 days: This is incorrect as 260 days equates to approximately 37 weeks, which marks the boundary between preterm and early term pregnancies. A pregnancy lasting 260 days does not align with the average duration of 40 weeks, which is the basis for defining term delivery.

questions.text: A 44-year-old G6T3P2A1L5 presents for her well-woman examination. She tells you that all of her deliveries were vaginal and that her largest child weighed 2900 g at birth. How many full-term pregnancies did this patient have?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 3. This question requires interpretation of the GTPAL system used to summarize a patient’s obstetric history: G (Gravida): Total number of pregnancies, including the current one. T (Term): Number of full-term deliveries (>=37 weeks gestation). P (Preterm): Number of preterm deliveries (<37 weeks gestation). A (Abortions): Number of miscarriages or elective terminations (before 20 weeks gestation). L (Living children): Number of living children. The patient is a G6P3215, meaning: She has had 6 pregnancies (Gravida 6). She has had 3 full-term deliveries (Term 3). She has had 2 preterm deliveries (Preterm 2). She has had 1 abortion (Abortion 1). She has 5 living children (Living 5). From this information, the number of full-term pregnancies is 3, which is the correct answer.

choices.text: No action is needed because the patient is asymptomatic, has not missed her period, and cannot be pregnant.
Order a serum quantitative pregnancy test
Listen for fetal heart tones by Doppler equipment
Perform a bimanual pelvic examination to assess uterine size

questions.text: A patient comes to your office with her last menstrual period 4 weeks ago. She denies any symptoms such as nausea, fatigue, urinary frequency, or breast tenderness. She thinks that she may be pregnant because she has not had her period yet. She is very anxious to find out because she has a history of a previous ectopic pregnancy and wants to be sure to get early prenatal care. Which of the following actions is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Order a serum quantitative pregnancy test. In this scenario, the patient’s last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago, and she is concerned about the possibility of pregnancy due to her history of ectopic pregnancy. A serum quantitative beta-hCG test is the most appropriate initial action as it is highly sensitive and can detect pregnancy earlier than other methods, often within 7–10 days after ovulation. Additionally, this test provides a numerical value for the hCG level, which can help differentiate between normal intrauterine pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy, or potential complications (e.g., miscarriage). Given her history of ectopic pregnancy, early confirmation and monitoring are critical for ensuring timely and appropriate care. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (A) No action is needed because the patient is asymptomatic, has not missed her period, and cannot be pregnant: This is incorrect because the patient’s concern about pregnancy is valid, especially with a history of ectopic pregnancy. Symptoms like nausea or fatigue are not mandatory for early pregnancy, and the absence of these symptoms does not rule out pregnancy. Additionally, a missed period is not the only criterion for considering pregnancy, particularly when a patient requests evaluation. (C) Listen for fetal heart tones by Doppler equipment: This is incorrect because fetal heart tones cannot be detected by Doppler equipment until approximately 10–12 weeks of gestation. At 4 weeks after the last menstrual period, the embryo is too small to produce audible heart tones, making this action premature and unhelpful at this stage. (D) Perform an abdominal ultrasound: This is incorrect because an abdominal ultrasound would not provide conclusive evidence of pregnancy at this very early stage. Ultrasound is typically more useful around 5–6 weeks of gestation when a gestational sac may be visible, or later when fetal cardiac activity can be detected. A transvaginal ultrasound could be considered if the pregnancy is confirmed and ectopic pregnancy is suspected, but not as the first step. (E) Perform a bimanual pelvic examination to assess uterine size: This is incorrect because at 4 weeks after the last menstrual period, the uterus is unlikely to show any discernible changes in size. Bimanual examination is not sensitive enough to detect pregnancy this early and would not provide the information needed to confirm or rule out pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the reproductive history of a pregnant woman who is 32 weeks pregnant with a previous twin delivery and a still birth at 32 weeks
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) G3P2L2. In the GTPAL system, the reproductive history of a woman is summarized as follows: G (Gravida): Total number of pregnancies, including the current pregnancy. P (Para): Total number of pregnancies that reached viability (?20 weeks), regardless of the outcome. L (Living): Total number of living children. In this case: The woman is currently pregnant, making this her third pregnancy (G3). She had a previous twin delivery (counts as one para, as it was one pregnancy) and a stillbirth at 32 weeks (also counts as one para because it was a viable pregnancy, even though the baby did not survive). Thus, she has had two prior viable pregnancies (P2). She has two living children from the twin delivery (L2), but the stillbirth does not contribute to the living children count. Therefore, her reproductive history is summarized as G3P2L2. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (A) G3P3L2: This is incorrect because P3 would imply that she has had three viable pregnancies that reached 20 weeks or more. However, she has had only two (one twin delivery and one stillbirth). The current pregnancy has not yet reached viability, so it cannot be included in the "Para" count. (C) G3P4L2: This is incorrect because P4 suggests four pregnancies reaching viability, which is not accurate. The woman has had only two prior viable pregnancies (the twin delivery and the stillbirth). The "P4" in this context would overcount her viable pregnancies. (D) G4P3L2: This is incorrect because G4 indicates four total pregnancies, which does not match her history. She is currently pregnant for the third time, so the correct count is G3, not G4. Additionally, P3 is inaccurate, as only two pregnancies have reached viability so far.

choices.text: The corpus luteum produces hCG throughout pregnancy
It is composed of two dissimilar alpha and Beta units
Levels double every 3 to 4 days in early pregnancy
Levels peak after 24 weeks of pregnancy T

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding hCG in your patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is composed of two dissimilar alpha and beta units. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a glycoprotein hormone produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta shortly after implantation. It is composed of two subunits: alpha and beta. The alpha subunit is identical to that found in other hormones like luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), while the beta subunit is unique to hCG and is responsible for its specific biological activity. This distinct beta subunit is the basis for pregnancy tests, which detect either the presence or quantitative levels of hCG in the blood or urine. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (A) The corpus luteum produces hCG throughout pregnancy: This is incorrect because the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta produces hCG, not the corpus luteum. In early pregnancy, hCG supports the corpus luteum by maintaining progesterone production, but the corpus luteum does not produce hCG. As pregnancy progresses, the placenta takes over progesterone production, and the corpus luteum regresses. (C) Levels double every 3 to 4 days in early pregnancy: This is partially correct but not entirely accurate. In early pregnancy, hCG levels double approximately every 48 to 72 hours (2–3 days), not every 3 to 4 days. This rapid increase is a hallmark of a healthy pregnancy in the first trimester but slows as pregnancy progresses. (D) Levels peak after 24 weeks of pregnancy: This is incorrect because hCG levels typically peak around 8 to 10 weeks of gestation and then decline, stabilizing at lower levels for the remainder of the pregnancy. By 24 weeks, hCG levels are significantly reduced compared to the first trimester peak.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain since the past day. She reports a 1-week history of nausea with occasional vomiting. She denies vaginal bleeding. She reports that her last period was 4 weeks ago. BP is 117/68, pulse rate of 78 beats per minute.. She notes some suprapubic abdominal discomfort with palpation, but she does not have rebound tenderness or guarding. A speculum examination reveals a closed cervix without bleeding. A pelvic examination reveals a normally sized, anteverted uterus, and palpably normal adnexa. A urine pregnancy test is positive. What is the test you should order first?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Quantitative level of Beta-hCG. In this case, the patient presents with abdominal pain, a positive urine pregnancy test, and no significant findings on physical examination to suggest acute complications. The most appropriate next step is to order a quantitative serum beta-hCG test. This test provides an exact measurement of the beta-hCG level, which is critical for evaluating early pregnancy. Specifically, it helps to: Confirm intrauterine pregnancy: The quantitative hCG level can be compared against the threshold for detecting a gestational sac via ultrasound (commonly 1,500–2,000 mIU/mL for transvaginal ultrasound). Assess for ectopic pregnancy: If the hCG level is elevated but no intrauterine pregnancy is visible on ultrasound, an ectopic pregnancy must be ruled out. Evaluate pregnancy viability: Serial hCG measurements can be used to monitor the doubling pattern, as hCG levels typically double every 48–72 hours in early pregnancy. Given the patient’s symptoms and her history of 4 weeks since the last menstrual period, assessing hCG levels is essential before proceeding with further diagnostic tests like ultrasound. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (A) Blood Type and cross: This is incorrect because while blood type and Rh factor determination are important in pregnancy, especially if Rh-negative, they are not the first test to order in this scenario. The immediate concern is to confirm the pregnancy’s location and viability, which is best assessed with beta-hCG levels. Blood typing is a subsequent step if complications like bleeding or Rh incompatibility arise. (B) CBC: This is incorrect because, while a complete blood count (CBC) can provide valuable information in cases of significant bleeding or infection, this patient has no signs of anemia, infection, or hemodynamic instability. Therefore, a CBC is not the most relevant initial test for her current presentation. (D) Pelvic ultrasound: This is incorrect as the first step because an ultrasound is most useful when the beta-hCG level has reached the discriminatory zone (1,500–2,000 mIU/mL for transvaginal ultrasound). Without knowing the quantitative hCG level, performing an ultrasound prematurely may yield inconclusive results. Ultrasound should follow once the hCG level confirms it is appropriate to visualize an intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 15 weeks of gestation by her LMP, presents to you for an ultrasound examination to confi rm her due date. Which of the following measurements on the fetus is the best at predicting her actual due date?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Biparietal diameter. At 15 weeks of gestation, the biparietal diameter (BPD) is the most accurate measurement for predicting the due date. The BPD is the distance between the two parietal bones of the fetal skull, measured via ultrasound. It becomes the most reliable predictor of gestational age and due date in the second trimester (14–28 weeks) due to its strong correlation with fetal development during this period. Unlike other fetal parameters, which may vary based on growth patterns or environmental factors, the BPD provides consistent measurements in the second trimester, making it the preferred method for estimating gestational age. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (A) Crown–rump length: This is incorrect because crown–rump length (CRL) is the most accurate method for estimating gestational age during the first trimester (up to 12–13 weeks). However, after the first trimester, the fetus begins to stretch out, and CRL becomes less reliable for predicting gestational age and due date. (C) Abdominal circumference: This is incorrect because abdominal circumference (AC) is typically used later in pregnancy, especially during the third trimester, to assess fetal growth and estimate fetal weight rather than gestational age. It is not as accurate as the BPD for predicting due dates in the second trimester. (D) Femur length: This is incorrect because femur length (FL) is a useful parameter for assessing fetal growth and estimating gestational age, particularly in combination with other measurements, but it is less accurate on its own compared to BPD. Furthermore, variations in fetal skeletal growth may affect its reliability for predicting due dates.

questions.text: A woman not currently pregnant who has had one previous termination, one early miscarriage and one still birth at 36 weeks. For this description choose the most appropriate answer
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gravida (G): The total number of pregnancies a woman has had, including the current one if applicable. Since she is not currently pregnant, we only count her past pregnancies. Termination: 1 pregnancy Miscarriage: 1 pregnancy Stillbirth: 1 pregnancy Total pregnancies = 3. So, G3. Para (P): The total number of pregnancies that reached a viable gestational age (usually 20 weeks or more), regardless of whether the baby was born alive or not. Termination (early): Not included in Para count. Early miscarriage: Not included in Para count. Stillbirth at 36 weeks: This counts as a "para" because it was a pregnancy carried past the 20-week viability threshold. So, P1. Therefore, even though she is not currently pregnant, her obstetric history is accurately described as G3P1. The G and P numbers reflect her past, not her present state of being pregnant. The only time the "G" number would change is if she became pregnant again.

questions.text: Match the column of hormones to their effects in pregnancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) PROLACTIN is produced by anterior pituitary and is essential for milk secretion. The levels of prolactin are increased 15 fold during late pregnancy HCG is one of the components of triple test the others are AFP and unconjugated estriol Oxytocin is released from posterior pituitary and is also called as milk let down hormone and has a half life of 3 mins HPL is responsible for insulin resistance in pregnancy and the levels increase as pregnancy advances with peak levels are seen in third trimester

questions.text: Match the columns of indication with the relevant vaccination in pregnancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Administration of influenza vaccine is recommended if the underlying disease is serious. • Typhoid immunization is recommended on travel to an endemic region. • Hepatitis A immunization is recommended after exposure or before travel to developing countries. • Cholera immunization should be given only to meet travel requirements. • Immunization for poliomyelitis is mandatory during an epidemic but otherwise not recommended. • Immunization for yellow fever is recommended before travel to a high-risk area. • Mumps and rubella immunizations are contraindicated. • Administration of rabies vaccine is not contraindicated during pregnancy

choices.text: Determination of uterine size on pelvic examination
Quantitative serum human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) level
Crown-rump length on abdominal or vaginal ultrasound
Determination of progesterone level along with serum HCG level

questions.text: A patient presents for her first initial prenatal visit after having a positive home pregnancy test. She reports a last menstrual period of about 8 weeks ago. She says she is not entirely sure of her dates, however, because she has a long history of irregular menses. Her urine pregnancy test in your office is positive. Which of the following is the most accurate way of dating this patient’s pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Crown-rump length on abdominal or vaginal ultrasound. The crown-rump length (CRL) measured via ultrasound is the most accurate method for dating a pregnancy in the first trimester, particularly when there is uncertainty about the last menstrual period (LMP). CRL can date the pregnancy with an accuracy of ±3–5 days when performed in the first trimester (up to 13 weeks). It is considered the gold standard for establishing gestational age because it directly measures the length of the embryo or fetus and is unaffected by factors like irregular menstrual cycles or implantation timing. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (A) Determination of uterine size on pelvic examination: This is incorrect because estimating gestational age based on uterine size is less precise. While uterine size can give a rough idea of the gestational age, it is subject to variability based on factors such as uterine anatomy, fibroids, or multiple pregnancies. It cannot match the accuracy of CRL measurement by ultrasound, especially in the first trimester. (B) Quantitative serum human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level: This is incorrect because hCG levels can vary significantly among pregnancies, even during the same gestational week. Although hCG trends (doubling every 48–72 hours) can confirm early pregnancy viability, they are not reliable for accurately dating the pregnancy. hCG levels are better suited for monitoring early pregnancy progression or evaluating potential complications like ectopic pregnancy. (D) Determination of progesterone level along with serum hCG level: This is incorrect because progesterone levels, while useful for assessing pregnancy viability, are not specific for dating pregnancy. High or low levels may indicate a healthy or nonviable pregnancy, but they do not provide accurate gestational age. Similarly, hCG levels are not precise enough for dating, as explained above.

questions.text: An 18-year-old G1 at 8 weeks gestation complains of nausea and vomiting over the past week occurring on a daily basis. Nausea and emesis are a common symptom in early pregnancy. Which of the following signs or symptoms would indicate a more serious diagnosis of hyperemesis gravidarum?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hypokalemia. Hyperemesis gravidarum is a severe form of nausea and vomiting in pregnancy that can lead to significant complications, such as dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and malnutrition. Hypokalemia (low potassium levels) is a hallmark of hyperemesis gravidarum and indicates significant electrolyte depletion due to persistent vomiting. This condition can lead to complications such as muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and metabolic alkalosis, making it a critical sign to monitor. Identification of hypokalemia warrants further evaluation and aggressive management, including rehydration, electrolyte replacement, and potential hospitalization. Reasons for Incorrect Options: (B) Hypothyroidism: This is incorrect because hyperemesis gravidarum is more commonly associated with hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism. Elevated levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in early pregnancy can mimic thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) activity, leading to transient hyperthyroidism. Hypothyroidism, on the other hand, is not typically related to hyperemesis gravidarum. (C) Weight gain: This is incorrect because hyperemesis gravidarum is characterized by weight loss, not weight gain. Significant weight loss (>5% of pre-pregnancy weight) is a diagnostic criterion for hyperemesis gravidarum and reflects the severity of the condition. Weight gain is not an expected finding in this scenario. (D) Proteinuria: This is incorrect because proteinuria is not a typical feature of hyperemesis gravidarum. Proteinuria is more commonly associated with preeclampsia or renal disease. While dehydration from hyperemesis gravidarum can cause concentrated urine, it does not typically result in significant proteinuria.

questions.text: Which is not correctly paired
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Amnion - trophoblast. This pairing is incorrect because the amnion and trophoblast are different structures. The amnion is the inner membrane that forms the protective sac surrounding the developing fetus, filled with amniotic fluid. The trophoblast, on the other hand, is the outer layer of cells of the blastocyst that contributes to the formation of the placenta. They are not the same structure, and the amnion is not derived from the trophoblast. Option A, blastocyst - implantation, is correctly paired. The blastocyst is the stage of the embryo that implants into the uterine wall during early pregnancy. It is made up of an inner cell mass, which becomes the fetus, and an outer layer of trophoblast cells, which help in implantation and placenta formation. Option B, ampulla - fertilisation, is also correctly paired. The ampulla is the wide, middle part of the fallopian tube, where fertilization typically occurs. After ovulation, the egg is captured by the fimbriae and transported to the ampulla, where sperm meets the egg for fertilization. Option D, morula - 16 cell stage, is correctly paired as well. The morula is the stage of early embryonic development when the zygote has divided into a solid ball of cells, usually around the 16-cell stage. This precedes the blastocyst stage, where the cells start to differentiate and form a hollow structure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest clinical sign of pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Amenorrhea The earliest clinical sign of pregnancy is typically amenorrhea, or the absence of menstruation. This occurs because the implantation of the fertilized egg and the subsequent secretion of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) prevent the normal hormonal cycle that triggers menstruation. The absence of a period is often the first noticeable sign that leads a woman to suspect pregnancy. It can occur as early as 1-2 weeks after conception and is usually the first clinical change recognized by the woman herself.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive test for earliest confirmation of pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Serum hCG The most sensitive test for the earliest confirmation of pregnancy is a serum hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) test. hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta after implantation, and it can be detected in the blood as early as 6-8 days after ovulation, making it the earliest and most sensitive method for confirming pregnancy. A serum hCG test can detect very low levels of the hormone, ensuring that it is the most reliable and early marker of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a positive sign of pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fetal heart sounds on Usg Fetal heart activity can first be detected on transvaginal ultrasound around 6 weeks of gestation. At this point, the embryonic heart begins to beat, and it can be visualized as a flicker on the ultrasound image. While a gestational sac may be seen earlier (around 5 weeks), fetal heart activity is generally not visible until 6 weeks when the heart has developed sufficiently to be detected with ultrasound

questions.text: Which sign refers to softening of the uterus during early pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hegar’s sign Hegar’s sign refers to the softening of the lower uterine segment during early pregnancy, typically around 6-8 weeks gestation. This sign is elicited during a pelvic exam when the clinician feels the softening of the uterus at the junction between the cervix and the body of the uterus. This softening is one of the early signs of pregnancy and is considered a positive finding in a clinical exam during the first trimester.

questions.text: Which of the following infections is NOT routinely screened for during the first antenatal visit?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cytomegalovirus Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is not routinely screened for during the first antenatal visit. While CMV is a common infection, it typically does not cause symptoms in most healthy individuals, and routine screening for CMV during pregnancy is not standard practice. Infections with CMV can lead to congenital CMV if the woman is infected for the first time during pregnancy, but screening is generally not recommended unless there is a specific risk factor (such as a known exposure to young children, or if the pregnant woman is immunocompromised). Therefore, routine CMV screening is not part of the standard antenatal care.

questions.text: The recommended daily folic acid supplementation for a pregnant woman with no prior history of neural tube defects is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 0.4 mg Folic acid supplementation is crucial during pregnancy to prevent neural tube defects (NTDs) like spina bifida and anencephaly in the developing fetus. For women with no prior history of a pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect, the recommended daily dose is 0.4 mg (400 micrograms). This amount is sufficient to ensure proper neural tube closure, which occurs very early in pregnancy (by the 28th day after conception, often before a woman even knows she is pregnant). Adequate folic acid intake supports DNA synthesis, repair, and cell division, which are critical processes during fetal development. Therefore, it is recommended that women of childbearing age and pregnant women start supplementation ideally before conception and continue through at least the first trimester to maximize protective benefits.
